  1. Introduction

    Friend is a mechanism to break the restriction on private/protect modifier.

  2. Friend function

    If a function is declared as a friend of a class, then it can access all the class static members and object members.

    #include <iostream>
using namespace std;

class F{
private:
    int p_x = 1;
    static int p_y;
    void p_Msg();
    friend void checkFriend(F & a); // friend function is not affected by the protected, private modifier.
protected:
    int pr_x = 2;
    static int pr_y;
    void pr_Msg();
    
    
};

int F::p_y = -1;
int F::pr_y = -2;
void F::p_Msg(){
    cout << "private msg" << endl;
}
void F::pr_Msg(){
    cout << "protect msg" << endl;
}


void checkFriend(F & a){
    cout << "private x " << a.p_x << endl;
    cout << "private static y " << F::p_y << endl;
    a.p_Msg();
    cout << "protect x " << a.pr_x << endl;
    cout << "protect static y " << F::pr_y << endl;
    a.pr_Msg();   
}

int main(){
    F f;
    checkFriend(f);
}

  3. Friend in inheritance

    Friend has a little intellgience when dealing with inheritance.
    Inside the child class/object, friend can access all the members that are inherited from the parent.
    If the child has overriden some of them, which means the child has its own version but has the same names as parent. In this case, the friend can still access the child's own member.
